vious and return home about one o'clock on Friday morning—when he came home I heard a quarrelling and a knock as if somebody was knocked down, and I went and demanded admittance at the parlour door—it was locked—I heard him knock her down—I went to the street door to call "Police," when my sister came out and put her hand before my mouth—I asked her if he had struck her—I asked her that twice, and she answered "No no, never mind, never mind"—I then went up stairs into my own bed-room, and then I came down and listened to them, and he wanted her to take a false

oath against me—she said, "I cannot, I will not take a false oath against my brother," and he replied, "Then I will do for you"—there had been some understanding between me and the prisoner previous to this—my mother was examined before the Magistrate—she has died since—she died on the 6th of Feb.—I can repeat several other former things.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. The misunderstanding between you and the prisoner resulted in his summoning you before the Magistrate? A. No, the misunderstanding was caused through my taking my sister's part—I never was before the Magistrate—I had been summoned before this mat
ter took place—the summons was to have been heard two or three days afterwards, on the Tuesday afterwards—this occurred on the Sunday—I am quite sure I did hear what I have stated—he wanted her to take a false oath against me, to swear I had committed an assault on him, which I had not done—the summons was for an assault—she said she could not take a false oath against her brother, and then he said if she did not he would do for her—I heard that distinctly—there were other wrangling words—afterwards I heard him say, "I will take a warrant out against you, I will transport you for seven years, if you do not take a false oath against your brother"—hesaid that several times, for I listened for two hours—he was intimidating her—they were quarrelling for upwards of two hours that night—he said he would transport her if she did not take a false oath against me—he said that first when I knocked at the door, "If you don't take a false oath against your brother I will do for you"—I stated that before the Magistrates—I lived in the house with him—he was the landlord—my mother lived there too—I have had frequent quarrels with him, but not with my sister, merely as you would say tiffs—when she had come up into my room I have ordered her out—I have ordered her out of the room, and just put my arm to put her out—I have not shoved her down stairs—Ihave not been threatened by the prisoner that he would have me up before a Magistrate for assaulting his wife—never for anything of the kind, not for assaulting his wife, only for assaulting him—he never attempted to assist her—he never complained of my assaulting her, or pushing her out of the room—my mother was not, as I am aware of, fond of interfering in their domestic arrangements—there were not constant complaints of her conduct made to me—I have never heard the prisoner say that he had no peace through his wife's mother—I have not heard him complain of her interference, nor of my sister's—my mother had not complained to me about it, nor has asked me to interfere—the prisoner and my sister occupied the back parlour, bed-room, and kitchen, and middle room on the first floor—I remained there after this matter took place up till the 16th of Feb.—I was there when the surgeon came—I did not, to my knowledge, see my sister shake hands with the pri
soner—I cannot charge my memory that I ever saw her do so on that morning—I do not know whether it might have occurred, and I forget it—I would rather swear it did not occur in my presence, but I would rather give him the benefit of the doubt—I cannot recollect it—it was nothing very particular to observe—I did not hear him say anything to his wife—I did not hear him say to his wife, "How did this happen?" or, "What did it?"—I only heard him repeat that once—I cannot recollect whether she did or did not hold out her hands and shake hands with him—when he said "Who did it?" she was lying on the floor, and she took no notice—that was the only time I heard him—I did not hear him say, "Who did it?"—I was not present then—Jo
nathan Cook was there—I fetched him—I was in and out of the parlour because I fetched Dr. Otway some water and some sponge—I could not have been there the whole time—I said at once that I thought he had cut her throat, from the threatening language—I did not say that he had done it—I might have said so, but I cannot recollect whether I did or did not.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did this assault which has been spoken of at all arise from any misunderstanding of that kind, about taking your sister's part? A. It arose out of this, one Wednesday morning she came up into my room and said, "My life is in danger," I thought it very strange for her to male that observation, and as I did not wish to interfere between man and wife I said, "Go out of my room," I looked over the bannisters and saw him going into the parlour, and I called him a cowardly villain—he took out a sum
mons against me on the 21st, and it was served on me on the 22nd—I was in and out during the time Cook was there—the shaking hands might have taken place without my seeing it.

JONATHAN COOK (police-constable P 254.) On Sunday evening, the 25th of Jan., I was fetched to the prisoner's house—I tried to get in at the front door—I could not—it was locked—I was obliged to get in at the window—I found the prisoner's wife lying bleeding, with her throat cut, on her back, in the parlour, near the parlour fire-place—the prisoner was holding her hands, apparently to keep her still—he had his shirt on, and a very great deal of blood upon it—she had her night-gown on and stockings, but no night-cap—the prisoner cried out to me what was he to do—Mr. Sharland, the milkman, was there and the brother—I said, "Send for the doctor immediately," and we sent for one—at the time the man was gone for the doctor the prisoner asked his wife who did it—she gave no answer, but looked very hard—I asked her who did it, and she looked very hard but gave no answer—she looked at both of us—we were both before her—I found this razor at the right side of the woman, and the left side of the man, about as far from her as she could reach with her right arm, and about where he was kneeling with his left knee—it was not quite close—there was blood on the handle, as it is now, and partly closed—Mr. Otway came to the door—he tried to come in—I asked the pri
soner for the key—he said he did not know where it was he was sure—Mr. Otway got in at the window afterwards—after she was removed to the bed I asked the prisoner where the key was, and he went to his coat pocket and took it out—when I asked him before, he said he did not know where it was, for he was out having a glass or two on the Saturday night—after that the prisoner asked her who did it, and I asked her who did it, and she laid still and looked very hard—she then rose herself up in the bed and shook hands with him, and kissed him, and pointed and showed him where some money was, which he found under the bed—I saw him take it from there—some pen, ink, and paper were given to her a few minutes after—the prisoner was there at that time—she then wrote these words on this paper—(producing it)—I took the prisoner into custody—she held up her fist at me, as though she dared me to touch him, and then I put my hand out and shook hands with him.

Cross-examined. Q. And when you did that she seemed pleased, did she not? A. I did not see any difference—she laid still and looked hard—when I took hold of her husband she still laid still—she first of all shook her fist at me, but after I shook hands she laid still—When she shook her fist at me I was not about to take him—I was talking to him, and she shook her hand at me and then put her hand out as though she would shake hands with him—she did before that, and kissed him—not then—Mr. Otway was in the room at that time, and the witness Vasey—the kissing and shaking of hands attracted a great deal of attention from all of us—we were all looking at it—I am quite sure it took place, and not very likely I should forget it—the prisoner appeared in a very distressed state to me—no doubt he was—he kept saying, "Who did it, who did it? how was it done?"—he said so three times.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. I suppose you were paying particular attention to the state of the woman? A. I paid attention to the woman and the man too—Icannot undertake to say what was seen by other persons—at the time of her shaking her fist at me I had not made any attempt to take the prisoner into custody—I only told him before her, that he must not leave the room—I was in my uniform.

ANN COX . I am the wife of John Cox, a brass-finisher. I am house
keeper to a person of the name of Coxhead, and live at No. 2, Halford
terrace, next door to the prisoner—I recollect on the morning of the 25th of Jan. hearing a noise, which was, I should say, about five minutes to eight o'clock—on my word I cannot describe what noise it was—I never heard

such a racketting in my life—it was a confusion, and I heard him say, "You b----b, you will halloo murder, will you?"—I cannot say it was the prisoner—Iheard a confusion in the passage of the house No. 3, and I heard a man's voice—I think it was the prisoner—they wrestled from the passage to the parlour, and then she must have clasped her hands by the manner of the sound—she said, "Oh you villain, you villain; you said you would; what have you done? you have done it at last"—I then heard her fall—I con
sider it was Mrs. Manton's voice—I am certain it was a woman's—he had beaten her on the Tuesday morning and on the Thursday night dreadfully—I only heard it from the sound the same as I heard then—he beat her shout half-past ten on Tuesday morning—I heard it again on Thursday night, at least I may more properly say Friday morning.

Cross-examined. Q. You seem to know all about your neighbour? A. No I do not—I do not know what they are doing all day at No. 1—I was first called on to give evidence on the 26th I believe—I did not come forward myself—inspector Collier found me out—I happened to repeat the words what I had heard when I went for our dinner ale, and then they came and called for what I had said—I have not been to a public-house to-day—I made the observation to I believe that gent—I did not think anything serious would have come of it, or else I would not have got into this mess I can assure you—I know he did the deed, although I did not see him do it—I heard quite sufficient—I do not know how the inspector found me—you had better ask him—I was brought here unwillingly—I came to speak the truth, and I do not care for any one—I told the people at the public-house what I thought proper—I did not suppose I should be brought here or I would have told them more—I have told you the whole truth and nothing but the truth—I do not drink gin.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. You went to the public-house for some ale? A. I did—I mentioned there what I had heard, and in consequence of that Collier called upon me.

JOHN SHARLAND . I am a milkman, and live at No. 26, Canterbury-place, Walworth. On the Sunday morning I saw Mrs. Munton's brother running towards Kennington-road, calling for the police—I went to the prisoner's house, and saw him leaning his body out of the window, beekoning for as
sistance to come—he was perfectly naked at that time—he came to the win
dow and said, "Come in for a witness, as I did not do the deed"—he said to me, "Put the question to her, and ask whether I cut her throat or not"—I made no reply—I put no question whatever, and he said, "My dear, did I cut your throat? did I cut your throat, my dear?" and she shook her head—themother came in, and said, "You villain, you said you would murder her, you said you would;" and the brother said the same, because she would not take a false oath against him—the mother told me that she came down and asked who did it; and that the poor creature rose her hand and said he done it—that was said in the prisoner's presence—he made no answer—I do not doubt but that he heard it, for in the confusion the mother was still bea
ting him with her hand, and said, "You villain, you said you would do it, you said you would do it."

Cross-examined. Q. She was striking him, was she? A. Yes—that was after his wife shook her head and said he had not done it—when I came in the pri
soner was quite naked—the mother came in afterwards—the prisoner came from the window where the blind was—he removed the blind aside—the mother seemed in very great agitation—I do not consider the prisoner was so much agitated as the mother and the son—they were scolding him—the brother said very little—I did not see Mr. Otway come in—I thought I would escape out

of the mess altogether, as soon as the policeman had come, and I put my foot out of the window—I did not see Mr. Otway at all—one of the expressions the prisoner used was, "Who did it? before it is too late"—she appeared it that time to be sinking rapidly, and the blood was flowing rapidly—I heard the mother say, "You villain, you said you would murder her"—I did not hear her say, "You have done it"—there was a great deal of confusion in the room at that time—the prisoner was stark naked, and bloody from the crown of his head to the sole of his feet—I got is at the window, the same as I got out—before that I had heard the brother hallooing for a policeman, from where I was—I was on my business at the time—when I got in at the window the blind was down, or partly down, and a great deal of blood about it, the prisoner came and pulled it on one side—it was a roller blind—when I went there the blind had not been pulled off the roller—it was not done while I was there—it was there when I went out.

RICHARD VASKY
re-examined. My mother gave her evidence at the police-court, and it was taken down in a book—her name was Susannah Vasey.

LLEWELLYN GUNN . I am clerk to the Magistrates at Lambeth. I recol
lect Susannah Vasey giving her evidence on the 20th of Jan., in the prisoner's pretence—I took down her statement in this book—she was sworn—(read)—"Susan Vasey, sworn, says, 'I am a widow, and live at No. 3, Halford-terrace, Penton-place, Newington. The prisoner is married to my daughter, Johanna; I have lived with them nearly a month; he has been married three years; he has very much ill-used her; the first thing yesterday morning I heard the prisoner call "Murder!" that was a little after eight o'clock yester
day morning; I ran down stairs, and met the prisoner at the foot of the stairs, without his shirt;. his wife was lying down on the floor, with her throat cut, and bleeding; I said to my daughter, "Who did it?" I and she pointed to the prisoner, and said, "You did it;" I slapped him on the shoulder as he passed, and said, "Oh, Fred, put your shirt on! look at your hands!" my daughter fainted away; he made no observation, but ran into the back parlour; he was sober; he came home about half-past twelve the night before; they slept together in the back parlour; it was in the front parlour she was on the floor; she had only her night-clothes on; I picked up a razor that lay on the left side of my daughter, on the floor; I called, "Police!" and gave the razor to, the policeman; the prisoner ran into the back parlour, and fastened himself in; I think the prisoner heard his wife say he had done it, and he made no observation, but ran out of the room; I called to my son; the key of the front door was lost, and I was obliged to open the window to key people in; I did not hear the prisoner say a single word; they had been quarrelling last Thursday night, and I heard her say, "I will not take a false oath for any. one," and I heard him say he would do for her; her face was dreadfully bruised some time ago; he has been in the habit of ill-using my daughter.

Cross-examined. I and my son lodged there, at 3s. a week; I am quite sure that the remark, "I'll do for you," I was not made by my son; I have not heard my daughter say anything about who did it since yesterday morning; I remained ten minutes with my son in the front parlour; when I first entered the room my daughter was on the floor; I did not observe her attempt to pull the wound open; her hands were lying down by her sides; her eyes were rolling when I first saw her on the ground, and she appeared quite powerless; she did not make use of any words but "He did it;" she raised up her handy, and said, in a low voice, "He did it;" I do not know if my son has received any notice from the prisoner to quit; I know that the prisoner took out a summons against my son.'"

Cross-examined. Q. Was this taken down word for word as the woman made the statement? A. It is the original statement taken down by me, word for word as it took place—she was not examined on any subsequent occasion.

CHARLES COXHEAD . I live in Great Bath-street, Clerkenwell. On Sunday, the 25th of Jan., I lived at No. 2, Halford-terrace, Penton-place—Mrs. Cox is my servant. About twenty minutes or a quarter past seven o'clock I heard in the adjoining house a man and woman quarrelling and fighting in the pas
sage—I distinctly heard two voices, male and female, but the parties are strangers to me—I know it came from No. 3—I heard a great deal of most foul and abusive language—I heard the man distinctly say, "D—n you, you will halloo murder again, will you," and I heard the woman immediately afterwards give a kind of shriek—they appeared to me then to retire into the front parlour—they appeared to be in the passage before—I went up stairs, and looked out at the first-floor window, and heard somebody call for assist
ance, for the doctor, and police, and call murder, but I did not go in.

Cross-examined. Q. You keep the Ben Jonson? A. Yes—Mrs. Cox was not with me when I heard this—I was in the front parlour—as soon as murder was called, there were five or six people collected—I was not flurried.

CHARLES WILLIAM OTWAY . I am a surgeon, and live at No. 11, Canter
bury-row. On Sunday, the 25th of Jan., I was called to No. 3, Halford
terrace, and saw a woman lying in the front parlour—the prisoner was by her side, with his left hand on her throat, and his right hand in one of her hands—he desired me to come in, and said, "You see what this has come to, Mr. Otway"—(I had been called in two days before on account of a quarrel which had taken place in the family, and I then gave them some advice, and left them)—I had the woman removed on to the bed, and examined her throat—it was a short, clean wound, about an inch and a half long, half sepa
rating the windpipe—blood was issuing from it, and also passing down the throat—it was such a wound as would be likely to be caused by such an instrument as this (a razor)—she did not appear quite sensible when I first saw her—I dressed the wound after some time—the prisoner was very much agitated during the whole time when the expressions were made use of by her friends—the wife made signs to me, intended to lead me to the opinion that she did it herself, and she several times shook hands with her husband, and caressed him—after she recovered a little, she spoke to me, but she could only speak in a whisper—I said if she had anything to say, she had better write it down, as she ought not to speak, but she said, "I did it myself"—she repeated it in a low tone—a paper was given to her, and she wrote on it—this is it—she at first wrote—(reads) "I did it myself through distress of mind; pray, my dear Fred., take care of our dear Arthur, for your poor Ann's sake; will you be father and mother for ever; do not charge my mother and brother with anything, they are innocent"—she signed that in the presence of the po
liceman and myself, at our request—I said to her, "Your mother and brother are not charged with anything; you have heard what your mother hat said, have you anything to say about your husband?"—she in great excitement wished to write again—I had the brother and mother, with the policeman, present, and she wrote these words, "Nor my husband," in their presence.

Q. What is your opinion as to the mode in which the wound was in
flicted? A. I consider a razor must have been taken, and the head thrown back so as to protrude the throat, and the razor just pushed there—I think if a man had taken the razor, he would take a sweep as if cutting his own throat, but a female would handle a razor in a very different manner.

COURT. Q. You think it was given by herself? A. I do—I think if it had been done by another person, it would have been rather a larger wound—if it had been deeper, it would have cut through the large blood-vessels—this had just cut the windpipe—it was not such a sweeping wound as would have been done by a man—if there had been any resistance or struggling, I think there would have been more wounds, or it would have been an irregular wound—it would be very likely to be a clean cut—I form my notion that it was done by herself, from the small extent of the wound, and the cleanness of it.

Cross-examined. Q. If there had been considerable struggling previous to and at the time the wound was inflicted, it was not at all likely to have pre
sented these appearances? A. Decidedly not—if it was inflicted by a man intending to cut her throat, it would have been a larger and stronger wound—ifthe head had been down, it would have cut through the carotid artery—the head being thrown up, would throw the windpipe forward, and that was cut through—there was no danger to her, except from the excitement the friends got her into—the mother was very greatly excited, and I told her if she was quiet I should be obliged to have her removed—she was saying he was a villain, and he did it—I had been called in on the previous Thursday, in consequence of a quarrel between the mother and brother and her—the prisoner himself sent for me then—I had never seen him before—he was not a patient of mine—he exhibited on that occasion affection and interest about his wife—she was then very excited, rushing out of bed, throwing herself on her knees to her mother, and begging her to leave the house—she exhibited no want of affection towards her husband—I believe the mother said they had been so often quarrelling, and the brother also, and he said he would not leave the house, being determined to protect her, but the whole time she was begging them to leave—it is decidedly my belief, having examined the wound, that it was inflicted by her own hands.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. How long were you there on the Thursday? A. I stopped a quarter of an hour—I understood that the quarrel was between the prisoner and Mrs. Munton and her family.

ARTHUR JOHN VASEY . I am the son of the prisoner's wife, and live with my aunt, at Shaftesbury-terrace—I recollect the Thursday night before this Sunday—I slept in the room with the prisoner and my mother—he came home at one o'clock at night—I went to bed in the dark in the back room—he and my mother were quarrelling in the front room—I heard a fall in the front room, and I thought it was my mother falling—they afterwards came into the back room where I was, and came to bed—I slept in the same bed with them—there was a rushlight burning—I saw him get out of bed and snuff it with a pair of scissors, and he put the scissors to his own throat, and said be should do for her—I afterwards saw my mother lying on the floor.

Cross-examined. Q. Who did you tell this story to first? A. The Magis
trate—my aunt Gillon I told first—I cannot recollect when—she did not ask me about it—I went and told her at her house—she came for me, and took me away—she did not ask me if they had quarrelled together—she asked me whether I saw Mrs. Munton on the floor—I told her yes—I do not know how she came to ask me that—she did not say anything to me about whether Mr. Munton had ever threatened his wife—I have been living with her ever since—I do not recollect when I told her this story the last time—I do not think I told it her yesterday—she told me to speak the truth—I did not tell her all I had to say before I came here this morning—I think I did not—I do not think she told me it was not quite right—she never set me right—I do not think I made a mistake when I told it her last—she is sister-in-law to Mr. Munton—I have heard her say she did not like him—she has not read over
anything to me—she took down what I was to say, and kept the paper—she did not show it to me afterwards—she showed it to the Magistrate and to Mr. Gillon, and he put it into the fire.
MR. ROBINSON Q. Your aunt came to fetch you away on this morning? A. Yes—I told her what I had heard on the Wednesday—she wrote it down, and I went before the Magistrate

ENOCH DAWSON HOWITT . I am a surgeon, and live in Apollo-buildings, Walworth—on Sunday, the 25th of Jan., I was called to the police-station, and saw the prisoner—he stripped before me—I found two scratches, as if by finger
nails, just below his right arm, a bruise at the back of the right arm, a bruise and scratch on the same elbow, on the left arm two scratches and a slight one below the elbow—the three first fingers on the left hand were cut, and the cuts were evidently made with the broad part of a sharp instrument—they were cut across about one-eighth of an inch—had I heard nothing of the trans
action, I should have said a razor would have done it—his shoulders were very much discoloured and bruised, and he was very much discoloured with blood—he said he was in the habit of sleeping without his shirt, and then he was stopped from saying anything more by the police, or he would have stated more—I saw his wife before I saw him—I think about half-past five in the afternoon—I did not see the wound in her throat—I saw the strapping—Inever saw the wound—I removed two strips of plaster to enable me to form some idea of the extent of the wound—I could see there was not a wound greater than the plaster—it extended very little beyond the wind
pipe—I could form a notion as to the position of the wound.

COURT. Q. Could you tell that there might be a wound below that, and if so that it could not have been inflicted by the party herself? A. It is im
possible for me to give an opinion—I could give an opinion the same as Mr. Otway has, if he is capable of forming an opinion whether the woman or the man committed it—I can form no opinion of it myself.

JOHANNA MUNTON
examined by MR. BALLANTINE. I know the charge made against my husband.

Q. On the night of this unfortunate occurrence did you cut your own throat, or did he do it? A. Yes, I did it myself—I have never said from the beginning to the end of the transaction that anybody did it but myself—my husband came out to me while I had the razor in my hand—I do not know whether he forced it out of my hand—I became insensible—I saw him come to me—he came close up to me—whether he forced the razor out of my hand I do not know—my husband never desired me to take a false oath against anybody.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. There was no quarrel between you and him that morning? A. None.

JOHN COLLIER (policeman.) I went to the house and examined it—I found blood in different parts of the room—I searched the prisoner at the station and saw marks of blood down his shirt and under his shirt, on his body down to his feet—he was covered with blood—there were scratches on his back—I called Mr. Howitt to examine him—the scratches appeared fresh, between his shoulders and on his arm.
NOT GUILTY .

789.
JOHN GLYNN was indicted
for stealing on the 20th of Feb., 871bs. weight of beef, value 2l.; the goods of
Solomon Bennett, and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months.

790.
EDWARD TRIGG was indicted
for bigamy; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

791.
CHARLES PERRY was indicted
for stealing 1 spade, value 2s. 6d., the goods of
George Feathers; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months.

792.
FREDERICK JOHN BARNES,
JOSEPH HENRY ADOLPHUS BARNES , and
CHARLES CARELESS CORK , were indicted for
stealing 84 cheroots, value 4s.; the goods of
George Rolls.

GEORGE ROLLS . I am a grocer and live in Red Lion-street, Richmond. On the 15th of Feb., about half-past six o'clock, Frederick John Barnes came into the shop to ask the price of bread—I was in the back parlour—he did not buy anything—a quarter of an hour afterwards the policeman came in, and I missed a box of cheroots—he produced this box, which I believe to be mine—it was safe a quarter of an hour before.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. How do these differ from cigars? A. In the shape—I suppose there are thousands of such boxes.

STEPHEN CREED (police-constable V 200.) On Sunday evening, the 15th of Feb., about a quarter past six o'clock, I was on duty in Red Lion-street, Richmond—I saw the three prisoners in company, come up close to the pro
secutor's house, they remained there three or four minutes—Joseph H. A. Barnes and Cork then came eight or ten yards down the street from the shop—and Frederick J. Barnes came away from the door and joined the other two prisoners, who were in sight of the door—they then all took to their heels and run away—I pursued them into King-street, where I took the two Barnes'—Cork made his escape—I found this box of cheroots on J. H. A. Barnes; I asked him where he got it from, he said his brother gave it him—F. J. Barnes said he had been to Mr. Rolls' for a halfpenny worth of figs, and took the box of cheroots and gave them to his brother.
Cross-examined. Q. How far were you from them? A. About the length of this Court—I took Cork the same evening, between nine and ten o'clock.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

F. J. BARNES—
GUILTY . Aged 13.

J. H. A. BARNES—
GUILTY . Aged 15.

CORK—
GUILTY . Aged 16.

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy.
Confined Two Days and
Whipped.

div1.p:
793.
HENRY BROWN was indicted
for stealing 1 ham, value 10s., the goods of
Joseph Tyrrell; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

794.
FREDERICK STENT was indicted
for embezzlement.

JAYNE PAYNE . I am landlady of the Hare and Hounds, at East Sheen, the prisoner was in my employ—I supply Mrs. Hampton with beer, which came to 8d. every week-day, and 9d. on Sundays—I supplied her every day from Sept. the 9th, till the 12th of Feb.—I supplied her on the 12th of Feb.—Idid not get the money for that day's beer till the prisoner was accused, and then he took 1l. 8s. from his pocket, expressed his sorrow, and said that was part of what he had taken, and he had spent the remainder—the money due to me was 5l. 6s. 2d., and the last that was owing was the 8d. for the last day, the 12th of Feb.—he ought to have brought me the money every day, from the 9th of Sept.
Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. There was no regular account was there? A. There was a bill made out at Christmas—he expressed his sorrow and gave up 1l. 8s.—he was a very good boy.
JAMES HAMPTON . I have had beer from Mr. Payne—I paid the prisoner regularly every day, except what we had on Sunday, which we paid on the Monday—I paid him 8d. myself on the 12th of Feb.
NOT GUILTY .

895.
MARY ANN SMITH was indicted
for stealing 32 yards of printed cotton, value 18s., the goods of
George Thomas Minor; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

HENRY EDWARD STREET . I am in the employ of George Thomas Minor, a linen-draper, who lives at Lambeth. On the 30th of Jan. I put four pieces of printed cotton outside the window—I saw them safe between eleven and twelve o'clock—I went to take them in in the afternoon, and missed one of them—this now produced is it—it is in two pieces now.
SOPHIA COLE . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this piece of print of the prisoner on the 30th of Jan., between six and seven o'clock in the evening.
WILLIAM AMOR . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this piece of cotton of the prisoner on Friday, the 30th of Jan.

HENRY EDWARD STREET
re-examined. These are my master's property.

JURY. Q. Are you able to swear to it? A. Yes—I believe the prisoner was in the shop with another person, just before I missed the cotton—I swear to this by the pattern, and it has been compared with a piece I cut off it, and it corresponds exactly—I do not suppose only one person had the pattern—this pattern I have in my pocket corresponds with the width of this cotton, and it was torn off a dress that I cut off this cotton—there were thirty-nine yards and a half of it, and I cut off six yards—I should not like to swear that the prisoner was in the shop, but I could swear to the person who was with her.

p.hi: The prisoner put in a written defence, stating that she had met her sister by Bishopsgate Church, and received the cotton from her to make dresses, and wanting to make a purchase at a bazaar, had pledged it.

div1.p:
THOMAS WILLIAM RADFORD (police-constable L 52.) I produce a certifi
cate of the prisoner's former conviction at Newington—(read—Convicted 14th April, 1845, and confined six months)—the prisoner is the person,

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Transported for Seven Years.

896.
WILLIAM LAPHAM was indicted
for stealing 1 horse, value 5l.; the property of
John Byars: and 1 cart, 2l.; and 5 sacks, 5s.; the goods of
John Byars and another, his masters.

JOHN BYARS . I am a baker, and live in Southampton-place, Nine Elms. I have been in the habit of employing the prisoner—on the 22nd or 23rd of Jan. I sent him out on various jobs, and the last time was with the horse and cart and five empty sacks—I gave him 3s. 6d. in silver to go for some saw-dust—he never returned—he ought to have returned the same evening—the horse and cart have not been found.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. When did this happen? A. About the 22nd of Jan.—it was on a Thursday—he was apprehended about the 10th of Feb.—he had been with me about two months, backwards and forwards—he eat and drank the same as I did—I had known him about eight months—this horse was Mr. Haywood's, but he lent it to me that I could let the pri
soner go out—I am in partnership with my brother James—if the horse had

been lost we should have been liable to pay for it, because we are in joint part
nership.

COURT. Q. Was the prisoner acting for your brother as well as for you? A. Yes, the cart was our joint property—the sacks belonged to my miller—they were in my trade, and I was answerable for them—the horse was lent to me, only on condition that my brother should sanction it.

ALFRED SPICE (police-constable V 41.) I took the prisoner for embezzle
ment—I did not say anything about the cart and the sacks—on the road to the station he said he sold the horse and cart at Smithfield, but he was tipsy at the time.

ROBERT PARFETT . I sell horses in Smithfield—the prisoner was standing at the hospital gate one afternoon, about three o'clock, with a black poney and a set of harness—I asked him who it belonged to—he said to himself, and he wanted to sell it—he said he would sell it for 6l.—I said if I could get a customer who would give him 5l. 10s., might I have what I could get over—he said I might—he said he had been selling sawdust.

GUILTY
of stealing the cart and sacks. Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

897.
MORRIS JOHN KNIGHT was indicted
for stealing lib. of cigars, value 8s., and 1/2lb. of cheroots, 4s., the goods of
James Bennett.

ELIZABETH CAROLINE BENNETT . I am the wife of James Bennett, tobac
conist, Belvedere-road, Lambeth—on the 11th of Feb., about half-past two o'clock, I was in my kitchen—I heard a bell ring which is attached to the shop-door—I went up and saw a young man in the shop—he asked for a cigar—I served him, and he left—I closed my gate after him and returned to my kitchen—I had not been there three minutes before I heard a noise—I went up and found the prisoner behind the counter—I am sure he is the per
son—his handkerchief was on the counter with three bundles of cheroots in it, which had been removed from the window—he had got hold of 8 fourth bun
dle in the window, and some of the cigars had been removed—I attempted to seize him—he knocked me backwards and ran out—I pursued—he was taken in Waterloo-road—I am sure he is the person—I never lost sight of him.
Prisoner. Q. Can you swear I stole those that were in the handkerchief? A. They had been removed from the window into the handkerchief.

Prisoner's Defence. I was half a mile from the shop; a man came and said, "You have knocked a woman down;" I said, "No", I have not, I will go back with you;" I went back and saw this woman; she said, "That is him."
Witness. I am positive he is the person—I have not the least doubt of it.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Months.

898.
KEZIAH WILLIS was indicted
for stealing 2 blankets, value 5s.; 2 sheets 2s.; 1 candlestick, 6d.; and 1 pair of tongs, 1s.; the goods of
Ri
chard Young.

SEELIE YOUNG . I am the wife of Richard Young—we live at Clapham—on the 26th of Jan. I let the prisoner a furnished room, and on the following Monday she left and took the key away with her—she did not come back—I went into the room on the Thursday week after she left—I missed two sheets, two blankets, a candlestick, and a pair of tongs—I have examined the sheet the constable has—it is my husband's—there is a mark on it.

Prisoner. I never went away till she put a padlock on the door. Witness. She had not paid her rent, and we could not see her—she was out from morn
ing till night, and, to find her, we put the padlock on.
MARY ANN SALISBURY . I keep a chandler's shop—the prisoner brought
a sheet to me, in great distress, and asked me if I would give her 6d. for it—I gave the same sheet to the officer.

Prisoner's Defence. My mother took most of the things back; she said if she had the whole of the things she did not wish to hurt me; I was in great distress: I intended to give them her back, and she said she would be satisfied.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined One Month.

799.
ELIZABETH WISEMAN was indicted
for stealing 1 shawl, value 8s.; the goods of
John Bassett.
CAROLINE BASSETT . I am the wife of John Bassett, of Upper Marsh, Lambeth. The prisoner lodged with us, and left while I was ill—I missed a shawl—this now produced is it.
CHARLES RUSSELL . I am a pawnbroker—I took in this shawl on the 30th of Jan. I believe of the prisoner.
EDWARD DIXON (police-cotistable L 85.) I took the prisoner—she told me I could find the shawl at Mr. Stevens's, where Mr. Russell is shopman—I did so.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Two Days.
(The prisoner's mother promised to take charge of her.)

800.
JAMES WEST was indicted
for stealing 2 pianos, value 5s.; 1 stock and bit, 8s.; and 1 gauge, 1s.; the goods of
Thomas Mellor.

THOMAS MELLOR . I am a carpenter, and live in Ely-place, South Lam
beth—on the 13th of Feb. I was working at a building which I locked up at five o'clock—I left there a stock, a plane, a gauge, a trying plane, and some other things, which I have not found—I missed them all when I went on the Monday morning—the plane, stock, and gauge produced are mine.
CHARLES RUSSELL . I am shopman to Mr. Stevens, a pawnbroker, at Newington. This plane was pawned on the 10th of Jan. for 1s.—I do not know who by.
CHARLES FRANKLIN . I am shopman to Mr. Fletcher, a pawnbroker. This stock and gauge were pawned on the 17th of Jan. by the prisoner—I am able to swear to him.
WILLIAM MORTON (police-constable P 289.) I took the prisoner—he denied it.
Prisoner. I pawned them for a man I met in London-road—I did not know him.

*
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

801.
CHARLES WEST was indicted
for stealing 1 gate, value 8s.; the goods of the
London and South Western Railway Company.

JOHN CUNNINGHAM (police-constable V 195.) I was on duty about a quarter past ten o'clock at night on the 18th of Feb. in the Wundsworth-road, and met the prisoner with this gate—I asked where he got it—he said he had brought it from St. John's Wood, he had bought and paid for it—I said if he would come with me I would show him where he brought it from—he went back with me about half a mile to Belmont-place, Wandsworth-road—I showed him where he took it from, and told him I had seen it there a quarter of an hour before—he said, "I did not take it from there, I took it off the path."
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. In what state was it when you

saw it? A. I saw it at ten o'clock lying on the ground where the houses have been pulled down—the front walls and gates are left—it was lying inside the premises which the South Western Railway Company have taken.

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined One Month.

802.
ANN MILLER was indicted
for unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

HENRY NUNNERY . I keep the Half Moon, at Rotherhithe. On the 2nd of Feb. the prisoner came to my house for a 1d. worth of shrub—she ten
dered me a sixpence—I said, "That is a bad one, and you know it"—she said it was all she had, and begged me to give it her back—I would not—I put it into a little snuff-box on a shelf in the bar—my daughter who serves in the bar saw me put it there—the next time I touched the box was when the policeman came to me on the 12th of Feb.—I marked it and gave it to him—nobody but my daughter and I knew the sixpence was there—I kept no other money there.
AMILIA NUNNERY . I saw my father put the sixpence in the box and put it on the shelf—I did not touch it till the policeman came—I was in the bar when the prisoner came—I am sure she is the person.

JAMES PHILLIPS . I keep the White Horse in Queen-street, Rotherhithe. On the 12th of Feb. the prisoner came in the afternoon, with another person about the same age—the prisoner asked for half-a-quartern of gin and paid a shilling—I looked at it and said, "It is a bad one"—she said she did not know it—I said, "Don't you recollect being at my house on Monday week tod giving my wife a bad shilling"—she said "No"—to the best of my know
ledge I had seen her there before—I called the policeman and gave him the shilling—I bad bent it and marked it with my pen-knife—this is it.
JOHN BAILEY WELLS (police-constable M 54.) I took the prisoner from Mr. Phillip—Nunnery marked this sixpence, and gave it me.
MR. JOHN FIELD . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. This shilling and sixpence are both counterfeit.
Prisoner. You will do me a great favour to transport me; I have no friends, and must return to the same bad line as before.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Six Month.

803.
JOHN WARD was indicted
for a like offence.

JOHN WOODLEY SMITH . I keep the Spread Eagle, at Rotherhithe. On the morning of the 9th of Feb., the prisoner came for a pint of porter, and took out a sixpence to pay for it—I took it up, Writ in two, and gave it him back—he was very abusive, and I sent for the policeman—he had taken up the two pieces of the sixpence, and when the officer came the prisoner put them down on the counter—the officer took them.

CHARLES SCOTT (police-constable M 245.) I went to Mr. Smith's on the 9th of Feb., and he gave the prisoner in charge for passing a bad sixpence—I found these two pieces of a sixpence on the counter—I took the prisoner to the station, and took 10 1/2 d. in coppers from him—there was a something rat
tling in his mouth—we tried all means to get it out, and could not—the ser
geant took a key, put it into his mouth, tamed it round, and out fell a bad sixpence—I saw another piece in his mouth, which we consider he swallowed, as we saw no more of it.
Prisoner. I sat down on a chair, and opened my mouth, and you broke
two of my teeth. Witness. You opened your mouth after putting the key in—wewere nearly three-quarters of an hour before we could get it.

HENRY HARDING MIDDLETON (police-sergeant M 2.) I searched the pri
soner, and got this sixpence from his mouth, which we opened by great force—heappeared to have another hard substance in his mouth, and to swallow it.

Prisoner. Q. Did you not tell me to sit down in a chair? A. No, I had you put in the chair, and held by two men, while I opened your mouth—youappeared to be drunk, but after we took the sixpence, you were per
fectly sober.
MR. JOHN FIELD . These two pieces are parts of a counterfeit sixpence—this other sixpence is counterfeit, and I believe cast in the same mould.

Prisoner's Defence. I had 5s., 6d., when I went out; I met with two or three men, and did not go to work; I generally put money into my mouth; I knew nothing about having the coppers; if I had wanted to get rid of the money, I had time enough to have swallowed both of them.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Six Months.

804.
FANNY GOLDSMITH , and
MARY ANN GOLDSMITH , were indicted for
stealing 251bs. weight of coals, value 4d.; 13lbs. of candles, 6s.; 81bs, of soap, 3s.; 1 yard of carpet, 6d.; 8 candlesticks, 1s. 6d.; 1 butter-stamp, 6d.; 1 cup, 3d.; 3 jugs, 1s.; 2 towels, 8d.; 1 printed book, 3d. 1 roasting-jack, 6d.; 1 brush, 6d.; 21bs. of coffee, 2s.; 21bs. of tea, 10s.; 2lbs. of butter, 2s.; 14 eggs, 1s.; 21bs. of sugar, 1s.; 1 tumbler, 10d.; 1 pot of jam, 1s.; 3 basins, 3d.; and 1 quart of groats, 6d.; the goods of
Angelina Pope.

WILLIAM FULLER (police-constable P 190.) On Thursday night, the 12th of Feb., I was watching the house of Mrs. Pope, and about eleven o'clock I saw Fanny Goldsmith come from her house, towards Camberwell—I stopped her when she got about 100 yards, and asked what she had got under her cloak—she said, "Some coals and wood"—I said, "Then you must go back with me to the house"—she produced two bags containing coals—she said she had them unknown to any one, and if I would let her go, she would take them back—I took her back, and Mrs. Pope gave her in charge—as I was taking her to the station she dropped a bag—I said, "You have dropped something"—she said, "I do not know anything about it"—it was a bag containing candles and soap—there was another policeman there, but there was no one else who could have dropped it—I took her to the station, and returned to Mrs. Pope's—the prisoner Mary Ann was there, and Mrs. Pope gave her in charge—I was taking her to the station—she said she knew no
thing about the things that were taken—she went a little further, and then said, "I suppose we shall both be transported"—I then went with Mr. Campbell to Fauny Goldsmith's house—I found there several articles of stolen property, and some duplicates—these are them.

Fanny Goldsmith. Q. When the policeman followed you from the Rye he said, "Stop, I have something here," and it appeared to be the bag? A. Yes, but I saw it drop from you, and heard it drop—I was turning back to pick it up when the other officer took it.

SAMPSON DARKIN CAMPBELL . I am inspector of the P division of police. I was at the station on Thursday night, the 12th of Feb.—the prisoner Fanny was brought in—I asked where she resided, she gave her address at No. 11, George-street, Camberwell, in the back parlour—she gave up some keys, and said the large key was the key of the parlour door; I should find nothing there but what was her own—I went and found a great quantity of things,

here is a candlestick, some remnants of carpet, a printed book, a roasting-jack, a china-pot, a pot of jam, a jug, and a butter print—the officer who was with me found some duplicates—I found some sugar, some candles, and some coffee, I went back to the station and told Fanny the next morning what I bad found—Isaid, "You said I should find nothing but what was your own"—she said, "I have done very wrong; I was wrong to do it, but distress for want of mans to pay my rent induced me; my child is innocent."

ANGELINA POPE . I am a widow and live at Peckham Rye—Mary Ann was in my service—she came on the 20th of Oct.—Fanny is her mother—on the 12th of Feb. I had a party, and Fanny was there, assisting her daughter in the kitchen—I had only employed her on that, and on one former occasion, but I have known her to be there on Sunday evenings, to see her daughter—these are my articles—I do not know when I lost them—I know I had some of them since Mary Ann has been with me—I kept the grocery goods and candles in a kitchen cupboard—it is usually locked and my daughter keeps the key and gives out the things—on the 12th of Feb. the cupboard was open most of the day—Fanny was at the house that day—she left at night and the policeman brought her back.

p.hi: The prisoner F. Goldsmith put in a written defence, stating that the sugar found at her house was her own, and some of the articles had been given to her daughter by the prosecutrix.

div1.p:
F. GOLDSMITH—
GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Confined Twelve Months.

M. A. GOLDSMITH—
NOT GUILTY .
(There were two other indictments against F. Goldsmith.)

805.
WILLIAM SMITH was indicted
for stealing 3 rugs, value 7s. 6d.; the goods of the
governors and guardians of the poor of the parish of St. Mary, Newington; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Three Months.

806.
FREDERICK JAMES PEPALL was indicted
for stealing 1 grate, value 5s.; the goods of
David Strachan, and fixed to a building.—2ND COUNT, not stating it to be fixed.—3RD COUNT, stating it to be the property of
William Obadiah Wheeler.

THOMAS WHITCOMB (police-constable L 89.) On the 3rd Feb. about seven o'clock in the evening I was on duty at Kennington, and saw George Baynes it the corner of Park-street—I heard a whistle and gave him into custody, I then got through an empty house, No. 59, Park-street—I fell over a grate in the yard—I got over to the next house and found the prisoner coming out of the back door with this grate on his shoulder, which I produce—I asked what business he had there—he said, "None"—I asked what he was going to the with the grate, he threw it down and struck me on the wrist with a piece of iron—another officer came up—I secured the prisoner and took the grate to the station—I am sure he had it on his shoulder, and his hands were all over soot found fresh lime, such as a person would meet with in pulling away a grate—I found five other grates had been moved, ready to be taken away, and one tad been taken from Nos. 59, 60, and 61, Park-street.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. All these were empty? A. Yes, they were three empty houses.

DAVID STRACHAN . I am a saddler—to the best of my knowledge, I know the grate produced—it belonged to a house in my possession—I have examined to place it was taken from—it had been fixed and was detached—I claim to hold this house as executor to a person deceased—it was in my legal pos
session—the houses Nos. 59, 60, and 61, Park-street, are part of the property

of the deceased person—there is a dispute as to the claims of the children which has left this property more immediately under my control till that is adjusted—the prisoner had no right to go to that place.

Cross-examined. Q. When had you last seen those houses? A. Four or five months ago, or perhaps longer—the tenants ran away, with the exception of the prisoner's father, who lived in one of them—I have the keys of some of the houses—a person named Hall has the key of the house from which the grate was taken—he was the tenant—he had paid rent—he owes twelve months' rent now.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 21.—Recommended to mercy.
Confined Six Months.

807.
JOSEPH GIBSON was indicted
for bigamy.

WILLIAM DAVISON DAY (police-constable K 74.) I apprehended the pri
soner at Rotherhithe, on the 12th of Feb.—I told him he was charged with bigamy—he said it would now be settled, and that it was his wish that it should be so—he asked me on our road to the Court what his imprisonment would be—I said I could not tell—he said his second wife knew of his first wife being living at the time, and that she was married again—I went to the church of the Holy Trinity, at Kingston-upon-Hull, on the 19th of Feb.—the mi
nister of the parish showed me the register, and I examined this copy with the orginal—it is correct—this is it—(read—certifying that Joseph Gibson and Mary Walton were married on the 18th of Dec, 1824.)

MARY ANN JORDESON . I am the wife of a person named Jordeson, living at Hull. I know the prisoner—I was present at his marriage with Mary Walton in 1824—she was alive last week, when I left Hull—she has never been from home—I do not think the prisoner and her lived together above three or four years.

Cross-examined by MR. WILDE. Q. The prisoner is a seafaring man? A. Yes—they lived together three or four years, and had a child—he was away at sea a year and ten months—when he returned his wife was far gone in the family way—that was the reason they parted—they divided the furni
ture and separated—I believe he has been in Hull, but I did not see him—I do not know that he has been there for seventeen years—his wife married again about two years ago.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was there any difficulty in his finding where his first wife was? A. No.
ELIZA MARY MILES . I am a widow. I married the prisoner on the 1st of July, eight years ago, at St. Saviour's, Southwark—I was in no business—I was protected by my brothers, who are since dead.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner had been living in the house where you were residing? A. Yes, he lodged there—since our marriage my mother and my son have lived in the house—the prisoner has not supported us all—my son has always been employed—I have some property of my own—I married the prisoner in 1838, and have lived with him ever since—my son was mar
ried in the summer—I gave him a bed and bedstead on his marriage.

COURT. Q. Did that lead to a family dispute? A. Yes—I understood the prisoner to have been married, and to have been away from home for years, under the circumstances that have been detailed—I expected him to deal fairly by me.

MR. WILDE. Q. Did he not tell you he had had no correspondence with his wife for many years, and did not know whether she was alive or dead? A. Yes—I spoke to Mr. Phillips—he did not advise me to inquire about it—I
did not inquire—I have taken all the furniture from the house, but it was under advice.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—Recommended to mercy
Confined Three Months.

808.
WILLIAM BROWN was indicted
for stealing 90lbs. weight of lead, the goods of
James Courthorpe Peache, and fixed to a building; and that he had been before convicted of felony.—2nd COUNT, not stating it to be fixed.

THOMAS FILES . I am clerk to Mr. James Courthorpe Peache—he is a timber merchant, and lives in Belvidere-road, Lambeth. On the forenoon of Satur
day, the 31st of Jan., my attention was called to the outside of the counting-house in the yard—I noticed that some of the lead pipe from the counting-house to the drain was cut away—on the next Monday morning I discovered that some further part of the lead had been removed from the ridge and round the chimney of the counting-house—the officer brought some lead, which turned out to have been removed from there—it was compared, and fitted the place—I had seen it right a few days before—the prisoner has been about the neighbourhood for some years.

JOHN OULD (police-constable L 87.) On Saturday morning, the 31st of Jan., I was on duty in Waterloo-road—I saw the prisoner and another boy coming along St. Andrew's-terrace—the prisoner had a bag—I spoke to his companion, and the prisoner dropped the bag, and ran away—he was stopped for me, and I took him—I said I wanted him concerning some lead—(I saw that it was lead in the bag)—he aaid, "I know nothing at all about it"—I took the lead to the prosecutor's premises, and compared it with the marks on his counting-house—it fitted exactly.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far from Mr. Peache's premises did you find the prisoner? A. 500 or 605 yards perhaps—I was gone from the bag for about five minutes to fetch the prisoner—I found it in the same place—I am sure it was the same that he dropped—I left a labourer with, it, who was passing by—he is not here—I looked in the bag as I passed by, and I found it in the same position.
CHARLES BURGESS GOFF (police-sergeant L 8.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, at Newington—(read—Convicted 21st March, 1842; confined three months—he is the person.)

809.
WILLIAM FRANKLIN was indicted
for stealing 32lbs. weight of lead, value 5s., the goods of
James Courthorpe Peache, and fixed to a building.—2nd COUNT, not stating it to be fixed.

THOMAS FILES . I am clerk to Mr. James Courthorpe Peache. I missed some lead from the corner of the counting-house on the 31st of Jan.—the officer brought the lead on the Monday following—we compared it, and it corresponded.

SAMUEL CORNELIUS . I am wharf foreman to Grissel and Peto. I was returning from dinner on the 31st of Jan., and the prisoner was pointed out to me as having a bulky appearance—I stopped him—I thought he had some tools of ours—I asked him what he had—he said, some lead he had found on the timber, and he produced one piece of lead—I said, I should call an officer—he then produced three other pieces—the counting-house where this lead was taken from, is five or six wharfs below ours, but those who gather the coals and other things walk through the mud.
WILLIAM GARRARD (police-sergeant L 18.) I took the prisoner with this lead—I
saw it applied to the counting-house—it fitted exactly—he said he picked it up.

Prisoner. I was told by a boy that he knew where there was some lead, would I come and help him pick it up; we stopped near the Chalk-wharf; two other boys picked up some; this was all mud; I washed it off, and took it on shore; when I was locked up Brown was there; he asked me what I was in for; I said, "Some lead;" he said, "That is the lead that I and Maton stole," and he told me how he stole it. Witness. There was some wet mud on the lead—there is free access from that counting-house to the mud—he had 32lbs. of lead about him.

JURY. Q. Was there more lead missed than Brown had in his possessions? A. Yes, 100lbs. was missing—Brown was taken about half-past nine o'clock, about 400 yards from the wharf—it would have been easy for him to have thrown lead into the mud. (See the last case.)
NOT GUILTY .

810.
JOHN OLPIN was indicted
for feloniously uttering a forged acceptance to a bill of exchange for 5l. 5s., with intent to defraud
John Bartlett.

JOHN BARTLETT . I am a broker, and live in Red-lion-court—I have known the prisoner about four years—on the 16th of July he came and requested of me to procure the sum of 5l. for him, to enable him to pay his rent, and he gave me the name of Michael Coney—I let him have 2l. on the 18th of July, for which he gave me an I O U, and the same day I gave him 3l. 5s., which made up 5l. 5s., and he gave me this bill of exchange for 5l. 5s., purport
ing to be accepted by Michael Coney, and the ink was not dry when he gave it me—I bud stated I would not advance the 5l. 5s. unless I had some security.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. You saw Coney before you lent the money? A. Yes—he said he had no objection to be bound for Olpin in the sum of 2l. or 50s.—he thought I came from a loan society, but I explained that I did not—here is the bill, and a eross under the words accepted M. Coney, and the ink was not dry when I had it for the money in Olpin's house—it purports to bear date 19th of July, and it was given me on the 18th—here is Olpin's indorsement on it—the acceptor cannot write—the ink-stand and pen were on the table in Olpin's house—it was about two o'clock in the afternoon—I stepped in quite accidentally, and he said, "It is all ready," or else I did not expect it till the following day.

COURT. Q. You went to the prisoner's house, he produced this cross, which was wet, and which purports to be the cross of Coney? Yes—I in
quired if Coney was there, and the prisoner said he was just gone.

MR. PARRY. Q. You took the bill away with you? A. Yes—when it became due the prisoner either called or sent to me to request me to hold it, and I wrote to Coney—I saw Coney about a month after it became due, and two months after it was given to me, and he told me it was a forgery—Olpin then told me it was accepted by Coney's son—I went to his son, and he denied it—when the bill was due I did not present it to the acceptor—I held it over for a month before I saw him—the money I lent belonged to Mr. Palmer, whose business I was transacting, and I communicated the fact to him—I applied to him for permission to lend to Olpin—I did not consider I was the person to prosecute the prisoner—Mr. Palmer gave him into custody.

MICHAEL CONEY . I live in James-place, Gravel-lane, and am a hair and size manufacturer—Mr. Bartlett came to me in July, about being security for Olpin for five guineas—I said, "If it were my own father, I would not"—I did not mind 50s., but no more—he sent me notice afterwards, and I went to Olpin, and said what did he bring my name in question for—he said there was some difference about Mr. Bartlett, and there was some bill—I went away and heard no more—Mr. Bartlett afterwards came and said, "About that bill of 5l. 5s."—I said, "I know nothing about it"—he went back to Olpin, and he told him it was my son—Mr. Bartlett came back and said, "It is your son"—I asked my son if he did it—he said he did not—it passed on from that time till the prisoner was taken to Union-hall, and they sent for me—I went, and said to the prisoner, "Did I do it for you"—"No," says he, "your son did it"—my son was not at home—I did not make this cross on this bill—I did not authorise any person to do it.

Cross-examined. Q. Can you read this bill? A. No—I do not know the contents of it—when I said I would not mind being answerable for 50s. I was not told I should have to give a written paper—I am not in the habit of mak
ing marks—I was security for Olpin to a loan society with another man for 5l. or 6l.—I laid hold of the pen then, and the clerk wrote my name—I did not make a cross—I have known the prisoner seven or eight years—I have seen, him as I have any other person in the street—I do not become security to lost societies for any other person I see in the street—I have only been secu
rity for him once—I believe that is twelve months ago—I will swear that on the 18th of July I was not at Olpin's house—I cannot tell what day of the week the 18th of July was—I will swear before God and man, that on no day about the middle of July I was at Olpin's house—I can do that honestly—I never was in any trouble—I never was in a court-house in my life, I am quite certain—I have never been in this gaol—I have never been indicted in this court or any other—I never heard of an indictment for perjury against me—I mean to swear I have never been indicted for perjury—I never was under a lock in my life yet, except my own door—I never dealt in cart-grease—I never was indicted for swearing that I did not receive a load of cart-grease, whereas I did receive it—I do not know Mr. Margeson of the new leather-market, Bermondsey—I will swear he never indicted me for perjury, nor any
body else, thank God—after this bill became due I did not go to Olpin's and say, "You had better say my son accepted it to get a little more time"—I am certain of that, and I never saw the bill till I saw it with Mr. Palmer.
PATRICK CONEY . I am the son of Michael Coney—I never put this mark on this bill.
Cross-examined. Q. Can you read and write? A. I can read very well—I can write as much as my own name.
COURT. Q. Do you remember your father being charged with perjury? A. No, I never remember his being tried for it—I never heard of it.

MR. PARRY. Q. Just remember—do not you recollect his being indicted for perjury, and being committed to gaol for it? A. No, I do not—I do not know Mr. Margeson of the new leather-market, Bermondsey—I do not remember my father ever being in trouble, or in gaol since I have known him—I have never been in trouble myself.
ISAIAH COHEN (police-constable M 210.) I took the prisoner—he said it was a bona fide transaction.

JAMES PALMER
examined by MR. PARRY. I live in Victoria-place, Stoke Newington-road—I was brought up to the watch trade—I have been a private gentleman for twenty-seven years—I do not do anything for my living—I lend a little money out now and then—I do not make a good deal by lending out

money because I do not do it to a great extent—I do it now and then—I do not know Olpin except through this transaction—I know Bartlett—he is my friend, and he is my agent in matters of this kind—I advanced this money to Mr. Bartlett, and he obtained the bill and said that was good security, pre
suming the acceptance was all correct.

COURT. Q. What money did you advance? A. 5l.—I was to have 5l. 5s. for it for one month—I do not know what that is per cent.—I am not scholar enough for that—we do things off-hand at once, and do not calculate the interest—I was told in Sept. last that this was a forgery.

MR. PARRY. Q. If this money had been paid he never would have been indicted? A. No, there would have been an end of the transaction—whether there would be an end of it if he would pay me now, I must leave to others.

SOPHIA OLPIN . I am thirteen years old—I am the prisoner's daughter. I know Mr. Coney—he and my father have been acquainted long—in June or July I saw Coney at our house—it was just before we had our dinner, or directly after—I do not remember the day of the month when he came in—a bit of paper was lying on the table—my father was writing when Mr. Coney came in, and said, "Olpin, I can't write, but you write my name; I will put my cross, that will do just the same," and he did so—it was a strip of paper like this.

MR. WILDE. Q. Do you write yourself? A. Yes—I was standing in the room against the door—I do not know whether it was before dinner or directly after—no one dined with us that day—the first time I saw the paper, it was on the table—I saw Coney come into the room—neither the dinner
thingsnor the tea-things were on the table—the door was open, and my father and Mr. Coney walked in together—they took chairs, and sat down by the side of one another, and then the paper was lying on the table—my father laid it on the table—I cannot exactly say where he brought it from—it was lying on the top of the books—I did not see what was on it.
NOT GUILTY .

811.
GEORGE REASON was indicted
, for that he on the 6th of Jan., and a certain man, whose name is unknown, in and upon
Mary Collins, felo
niously did make an assault, putting her in corporal fear and danger of her life, and feloniously did rob and steal from her person, and against her will, 1 frying-pan, value 1s. 6d.; and 1s.; her property; and immediately before, at the time of, and immediately after the said robbery, did beat, strike, and use personal violence to her: and that he had been before convicted of felony.

MARY COLLINS . I am single, and live in Tyer's-street, Vauxhall. On the 6th of Jan. I had been at work at Camberwell New-road—when I came out about seven or eight o'clock at night, I saw the prisoner and another, whom I do not know, in the street—I had a basket on my head, and a frying-pan—the prisoner put his arms round me, and pushed me against the gate in the road—I went in and waited a little while till I thought they were gone—I then went on, and saw them again—they used very bad language, and as I got to Kennington-oval, they came up to me—the other one laid he would rip my b—y guts open—he put an open knife against my breast—he took it out, opened it, and put it against my breast—he said something about money, but I was frightened and do not know what he said—he then dropped the knife, and kicked me violently in the lower part of the belly—it gave me so much pain, I could not stand upright—he then held me, while the pri
soner gave me two or three blows in the side, and then kicked me—he

snatched the basket from me, and looked into it—he threw it back to me—there was not anything worth while in it—he then snatched the frying-pan from me, and rolled me in the mud—he put his hand into my pocket—I said, "Don't rob me"—he struck me again between the shoulders—he said, "You old b—, I have done for you"—they then ran away round the Oval—I felt in my pocket directly, and missed a shilling, which I know was safe after they first spoke to me—I was going round the Oval, and saw the other man—he whistled, and then called, "Punch, it is all right"—the prisoner then came up and joined the other man—the prisoner saw me, and said, "You old b—, I thought I had done for you"—then they went away together.
Prisoner. I know nothing about it. Witness. I am certain he is the man if I were to die this minute—I am well known in Lambeth—I had never seen him before.

Prisoner. On the 31st of Jan. I came down Kennington-lane; this woman came and said, "That is Punch, I think it is him; "she said I took a frying
pan out of her hand, and lifted up her gown, took a shilling out of her pocket, and then she said I took a basket out of her hand; there was nothing in it, and I threw it at her, and she said the other one did nothing to her; I was remanded four times, and she never came, and said nothing till last Mon
day; I do not know her at all.

THOMAS FARMER WHITCOMB (police-constable L 89.) I took the prisoner—I showed him and three others to Collins, and she identified him as being the person who robbed her—she said he had sore eyes, and she picked him out—he goes by the name of Punch.

Prisoner's Defence. I know nothing about it; I think the policeman has put it into her head, to get a few shillings; because I go by the name of Punch, if there is anything done, I am to be taken for it.

SAMUEL HOCKADAY (police-constable L 10.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction by the name of James Purdy—(read—Con
victed 3rd Feb., 1845, and confined six months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, 30TH OF MARCH.
